name: Factory Incident/Last Burning Embers - Split 7"
description: The limited edition split 7" single between Washington DC's The Factory Incident and NYC’s Last Burning Embers (featuring Jack Rabid of Springhouse/Big Takeover on drums) was released in late September. Limited to 250 copies and designed by The Wax Museum artist and musician Jack Duckworth (Radio Berlin, A Luna Red).

name: Librarians - Present Passed
description: Librarians follow up their debut full-length, Alright Easy Candy Stranger, by delving into the catalogs of baroque pop and new wave without abandoning the viscous dance-punk that first captivated audiences in their home state of West Virginia. File "Candy Season" under B for boat drinks, bouncy psychedelia and beaches. "Cranberry Palace" belongs amongst the 60's heartbreakers, between the charm of The Turtles and the pitch perfect humility of The Zombies. On "Marilla Park" the band channels the smooth delivery of Clinic with a hint of Echo and the Bunnymen. Appalachia may not seem to be the first place you'd look for weird, kaleidoscopic party jams, but with Present Passed Librarians continue to defy easy classification.

name: Dawn of Man - In The Bronze Age
description: The revolutionists that form Dawn of Man have been spreading their musical fury for nearly two decades. Brian Clancy formed one half the guitar attack of Washington, DC's Bluetip and has been grinding his teeth on his fretboard since the old Baltimore/DC basement punk days of his previous bands, Downer Boys and Blind Ambition. The latter, a hardcore band in which speed and thud psychotically coexisted, marked the first collaboration between Clancy and TV on the Radio's David Sitek. Sitek, deviser of the NYC dance-punk sound that grew from the Brooklyn rehearsal rooms of bands like Yeah Yeah Yeahs and Liars to an international explosion, returns to the fold to brings his expertise as a producer to DOM's debut EP, In the Bronze Age. Confrontational and intimate, singer Alison Russell's voice is Michael McDonald’s beard grown into the 19 year-old throat of Exene Cervenka. She jumps in hard on every line even if it’s only to whisper that she wont let you go. Jim and Andrea make up the rhythm section, pounding together New Order's clanging drums with Jesus Lizard's overdriving bass. They give Sitek the open sesame to his production gifts, a backbeat that's an inseparable part of each song's emotional substance. The melodic pop heart of the EP, Dart Shipe's keys and Brian's layered feedback and guitar riffs, makes Siamese twins of Head on the Door-era Cure and Nightlife-era Thin Lizzy. "Bronze Age," the second track, lyrically revels in the idea of a lawless and boundlessly creative civilization. As the anthem of minor chords descends into a coda, the rhythm section pulls back, and piano and guitars play what feels like a soundtrack to a desolate vista of a human age driven to bigger and better things. "Its time to burn/in the Bronze Age/we are making things beautiful/I do what I want/because I've got no rules/I've got no laws."

name: Technostress - S/T
description: Technostress are a band divided by two coasts. Treiops Treyfid (formerly of Pitchblende) lives in Los Angeles, Aimee Soubier and Karl Hill (both formerly of Factory Incident) reside in Washington, DC. This method of making and performing music is considered impractical, chaotic and ridiculous. The band toured in 2007.

name: Factory Incident - Redtape
description: Redtape was recorded by Don Zientara at Inner Ear Studios and mixed by J. Robbins (Channels/Burning Airlines/Jawbox). The songs span a period of three years since the release of the band’s debut recording Helmshore EP in 2001 and represent a significant shift in musical direction. Whereas Helmshore EP was characterized by shimmering guitar work, spare bass lines and an emphasis on atmospherics, Redtape is a more brash and angular affair. The six tracks on this recording expand on the broad range hinted at on their debut: dissonant melodies, intricate and compelling songs. The guitars vary from textured to minimalist, yet with a conscious restraint. John Stabb’s (ex-Government Issue) vocals provide a rare dramatic bent that takes the uninitiated by surprise. The songs overall are epic and emotional like the best of their post-punk influences of the 80’s decade but concise with minimal filler.
